awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Studies of Accelerated Low Temperature Combustion Kinetics by Nonequilibrium Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
1402640
Lempert

Plasmas are often used to facilitate burning of fuels, especially those either difficult to ignite or to sustain burning, as they might be burning at low temperatures.  This proposal focuses on obtaining data that would help to understand how plasmas facilitate fuel burning under these unfavorable conditions.  A collaborative arrangement will be established between the co-PIs and the Dublin, OH city school system.  This outreach program will include live in-classroom demonstrations, virtual classroom visits, and participation in the Dublin Professional Internship Program.  The program will also advance "discovery and understanding" in several ways.  In addition to the participation of graduate students, the program will include active participation of undergraduates.  The program will also significantly impact the scientific infrastructure in the U.S (and the world).  In particular, the low temperature data sets generated from this program will be made available to researchers world-wide for model development and validation.  The co-PIs and students are regular contributors to scientific meetings in the U.S. and abroad, and maintain a comprehensive web site.

The proposed program focuses on experimental and modeling studies of the acceleration of low temperature combustion kinetics by non-equilibrium plasmas.  The goal is to generate extensive sets of benchmark low temperature (~400 - 850K) data that will provide new physical insight into the most important plasma-enhanced fuel oxidation processes in H2/air and a variety of hydrocarbon/air mixtures, in particular the role of non-equilibrium vibrational and metastable electronic state species and large non-equilibrium pools of key radical species such as O, H, and OH.  The methodology will utilize an extensive suite of laser diagnostics to perform measurements of the temporal evolution of electron density and temperature, heavy species rotational/translational temperature, N2 and H2 vibrational distribution function, and selected species concentrations after application of a single nano-sec duration discharge pulse.   Experiments will be performed in a complimentary pair of nano-second plasma discharge cells, both of which will produce diffuse plasmas with excellent optical access.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Time evolution of electron density and electron temperature is measured in a diffuse filament nanosecond pulse electric discharge in hydrogen-helium and oxygen-helium mixtures. At all experimental conditions, a rapid initial rise of electron temperature and electron density during the discharge pulse is observed, followed by the decay in the afterglow. Electron density in the afterglow decays more rapidly as hydrogen or oxygen fraction in the mixture is increased. Peak electron number densities and electron temperatures exceed 1014 cm-3 and 5 eV, respectively. The experimental results in helium and O2-He mixtures are compared with kinetic modeling predictions, showing good agreement. The results demonstrate that kinetic processes of ionization, electron-ion recombination, and electron attachment in H2 and O2 containing ns pulse discharge plasmas, used for plasma assisted ignition and combustion augmentation, are well understood.


Time-resolved OH number density, nitrogen vibrational temperature, and gas temperature are measured in nitrogen, air, and hydrogen-air mixtures excited by a diffuse filament nanosecond pulse discharge. The main objective of these measurements was to study kinetics of OH radicals at the conditions of strong vibrational excitation of nitrogen, below ignition temperature. The results show that the discharge generates strong vibrational nonequilibrium in air and hydrogen-air mixtures, with peak vibrational temperature of 1900 K at the gas temperature of approximately 500 K. Comparison of the experimental data with kinetic modeling predictions shows that OH kinetics is controlled primarily by reactions of H2 and O2 with O and H atoms generated during the discharge. The results demonstrate that vibrational excitation of N2 does not have a direct effect on OH formation and decay in ns pulse discharge plasmas used for ignition and combustion augmentation. Temperature rise caused by N2 vibrational relaxation by O atoms does result in transient OH number density overshoot, which is a dominant effect in discharges with specific energy loading.


Time-resolved, absolute number densities of H atoms and O atoms are measured in preheated, diluted H2-O2-Ar, CH4-O2-Ar, C3H8-O2-Ar, and C2H4-O2-Ar mixtures excited by a repetitive nanosecond pulse discharge at pressures ranging from 300 Torr to 700 Torr. The results are compared with kinetic model predictions, showing good agreement. In ns pulse discharge plasmas, significant fractions of H2 and O2 initially available in the mixture are efficiently dissociated, up to nearly 100% in diluted O2-Ar mixtures. Up to 50% of discharge input energy goes to generation of H and O atoms. The dominant kinetic processes of formation and decay of H and O atoms in the plasma and in the afterglow are well understood. O atoms produced in the plasma oxidize significant fractions of hydrogen and hydrocarbon fuel species in the mixture. However, at temperatures significantly below ignition temperature, chain branching reactions have a minor effect on fuel oxidation.


Time-resolved, absolute NO and N atom number densities are measured in a diffuse plasma filament, nanosecond pulse discharge in dry air, hydrogen-air, and ethylene-air mixtures. The results are compared with kinetic modeling calculations, showing that in air plasmas, NO decay occurs by the reaction with N atoms, NO + N → N2 + O. In the presence of hydrogen or ethylene in the plasma, this reaction is mitigated by reaction of N atoms with OH, N + OH → NO + H, resulting in considerably higher NO number densities. Kinetics of NO formation and decay in air and H2-air plasmas are well understood. The present experimental results demonstrate that NO kinetics in hydrocarbon-air plasmas is more complex, and their analysis requires further development of predictive kinetic models.

 

Electric field during ns pulse discharge breakdown in diffuse plasmas generated in ambient air and in an atmospheric pressure hydrogen diffusion flame has been measured. Electric field dynamics in ns pulse discharges in air is well understood. Electric field during ns pulse breakdown in hydrogen diffusion flames is significantly lower compared to that in ambient air, due to higher temperature of the combustion products. Both in air and in the flame, the electric field follows the applied voltage before breakdown and decreases rapidly after breakdown. Electric field measured in air is in good agreement with kinetic modeling predictions. A detailed kinetic model is needed to obtain quantitative insight into the electric field dynamic in reacting fuel-air mixtures. The present diagnostics will have much better sensitivity in high-pressure flames, since the signal is proportional to pressure squared.


These results will have a major impact on future development of low-temperature plasma ignition, combustion, and flameholding applications. Also, the present experiments provided an extensive set of data for validation of state-specific kinetic models of nonequilibrium reacting molecular plasmas, significantly enhancing their predictive capability for related fields, such as plasma flow control, plasma materials processing, and plasma biomedical applications.  

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2017
Modified by: Igor V Adamovich
